constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT
VALUER Type: VALUERSDescription: Housing HRA

description: Conversion of a ground floor into a 1x bedroom flat. Erection of a rear single storey extension with external access and installation of 1x window and 1x balcony to front elevation. Erection of a bike store and alterations to playground layout
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: To comply with the provisions of Section 91(1)(a) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 as amended by the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby approved shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No work relating to the development hereby approved, including works of demolition or preparation prior to building operations, shall take place other than between the hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 to 13:00 Saturdays and at no time on Sundays or Bank or National Holidays. Reason: To protect the occupiers of neighbouring properties from noise and disturbance outside the permitted hours during the construction period, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the first occupation of the hereby approved development, details of the cycle parking storage including the number of cycles it can accommodate and the specification of any cycle storage solutions that would be used shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall be implemented in full accordance with the details as approved under this condition prior to the first occupation and retained as such thereafter. Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the first occupation of the hereby approved development, a waste and recycling management plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme shall include the following details: a) The number and size capacity of the refuse and recycling binsb) The location of the bin store facility The development shall be implemented in full accordance with the details as approved under the waste and recycling management plan and retained as such thereafter. Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the first occupation of the hereby approved development, the ground floor rear elevation window serving the bathroom shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the future occupiers and existing occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The dwelling hereby approved shall be used as self-contained residential units as shown in the hereby approved drawings under Class C3 (a) and no other purpose (including any other purpose in Class C3 or C4 of the Schedule to the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987, or in any provision equivalent to that Class in any statutory instrument revoking and re-enacting that Order, with or without modification). Reason: To enable the Local Planning Authority to exercise control of the type of use within the category in order to safeguard the amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a detached dwelling. 9 surrounding properties were notified of the proposal. One objection was received, relating to impacts to trees, loss of light/sunlight, loss of privacy, excessive height and bulk of buildings.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- ParkingWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officers comment: The proposed two storey side extension would be set back by 1m by the front elevation and 0.8m from the boundary with no.21, which is less than what is recommended by the Residential Design Guide SPD for two storey side extensions. Within the area there is a mixture of terraced and semi-detached houses; the semi-detached dwellings all retain relatively uniform gaps between the boundaries, including neighbouring property no.21 with a separation distance of 1.1m. Officers also note that the proposed two storey side extension would be a similar width to the original dwelling. Side extensions should be subservient to the original dwelling, and as there are no extensions of a similar scale in the area it is considered that the proposed extension would be out of keeping with the surrounding area. The roof form for the two storey side extension would be set down from the existing roof and thus be subservient to the applicants dwelling. The rear extension would have a depth of 4m and a flat roof with a height of 3.15m to the eaves. While the depth would be in scale with the detached dwelling the height would be excess of that recommended by the Residential Design Guide SPD which proposes flat roofs to be a maximum height of 3m. Given the width of the two storey side extension, proximity of the rear/side extension to No.21 Kings Avenue, and height of the single storey rear/side extension it is considered that the development would create an incongruous addition to the existing dwelling and surrounding area. Having regard to the above, the proposed development is not considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbanceThe single storey side extension would be set back from the boundary with No.21 Kings Avenue by 0.8 metres and extend the full depth of the dwelling, with an additional 4m extension to the rear. The height of the side and rear extension would be 3.15m with a flat roof, over what is recommended by the Residential Design Guidelines SPD. Although the rear extension would be of a modest depth for a detached dwelling, neither adjoining properties to the applicants property benefit from existing extensions, and are already set back from the line of the existing rear of the applicants property. Even though the rear development has an excessive height, it is unlikely that No. 15 Kings Avenue would be unduly affected by the proposed development given that there is an existing outbuilding that borders the applicants property and would adjoin the proposed rear extension and limit any impact to loss of amenity. However, the proposed developments would be coming in close proximity to the boundary with No. 21 Kings Avenue, and given the depth of the side and rear extension combined, would ultimately result in a feeling of overbearing. Further, given the depth, height and proximity of the developments it is not likely that the development would pass the 45 degree test resulting in a loss of sunlight and outlook for the neighbouring property.The two storey side extension has windows which are obscure glazed and are non openable below 1.7m from first floor landing, limiting the impact of overlooking to neighbouring property No. 21 Kings Avenue. However, given the proximity of the development to the boundary line, it is likely that there would be adverse impacts to sunlight and overbearing for neighbouring property No. 21 Kings Avenue. Having regard to the above, it is considered that the proposed development would adversely  affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officer comment: Permeable block paving is proposed to replace the existing hard standing to the front of the applicants property. A dropped kerb is also proposed to add one new parking space. A street tree is located to the front of the property in close proximity to the proposed dropped kerb, and given its close proximity to the proposed development it is likely to have to be removed if permission was granted. Given that the Sustainable Transport SPD advises against the felling of street trees, the proposed dropped kerb would not comply with recommendations as set out in this SPD. In conclusion, the proposed development would be excessive and incongruous and would not relate well to the host dwelling or the surrounding area, resulting in harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposed development would also result in an unacceptable adverse impact upon neighbouring residential amenity in terms of loss of sunlight/light and a sense of overbearing for both neighbouring properties. Further, given the impact the dropped kerb would have to the street tree to the front of the property, the proposal is therefore contrary to Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.

The assessment has been based on the original layout of the house that shows a rear outrigger according to council records.  The proposed extension would therefore extend beyond the side elevation of the outrigger and would have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (j) (iii) and (ja) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) and would require planning permission.

The proposals also show works which may fall outside the parameters of permitted development such as amendments to the fenestration on the first floor. It is also not clear if any excavation works would be required as part of the changes shown to the basement on the proposed floor plans.
Conditions 3 (Facing materials) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.

Condition 4 (Cycle facilities) and 5 (Refuse and recycling facilities) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and due to inconsistent drawings, have concluded that these conditions cannot be approved at this time.
Condition 7 (Soft landscaping) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.

Condition 8 (Construction logistics plan) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are not satisfied with the information provided, therefore concluded that this condition cannot be approved at this time.

I acknowledge receipt of your payment for £ 750.00, the fee required for this application is £ 1250.00 (Category D), therefore please forward the outstanding balance of £500.00 as soon as possible.Note: Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or online via the Kingston council website.

The fee required for your pre planning application is £145.00.  Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or online via the Kingston council website.

Please note that the quality of advice will be proportionate to the level of information provided, therefore it is to the applicants benefit to provide as much supporting information as possible for the proposal. eg: plans and elevations, photographs and supporting documents.

The fee required for your pre planning application is £ 250.00.  Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or online via the Kingston council website.
Please be advised that a fee of £96 is required for this application. This can be paid either online at www.kingston.gov.uk or by calling our Customer Service Team on 020 8547 5002
Please note that the submitted plans are not to scale and do not measure accurately to the scale bar shown. Please ensure the submitted floor plans and elevations are to scale and resubmit
